info.caption: Why is this a special property?
info.para: To appreciate this property of linear functions, we need to be aware that arbitrary functions need to have it. Consider, for example, the constant function f\from \RNr\to \RNr, f(x)=1. It has f(0)=1\neq 0. So even this simple function f fails to have the property L(\Vect{0})=\Vect{0} that all linear functions have.
In particular, f is not linear.
Linear maps must send zero vector to zero vector. If a given function fails to have this property, it cannot be linear. Here are some examples of this type.
Warning There are functions which satisfy f(\Vect{0}) = \Vect{0}, but still f is not linear.
Examples of linear maps which send \Vect{0} to \Vect{0} but are not linear
